description: 1-2. Joins three sections of plaster mold.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 3. Attaches the molds using a wooden frame and bolts so that the mold will withstand pressure. A rubber board is placed as cushioning between the wooden frame and the mold.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 4. Porcelain slip is mixed.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 5. The slip is filtered through a sieve approximately 100 times.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 6. The filtered slip is placed in a pressurized tank.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 7. The tank is completely sealed.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 8-9. The hose from the pressurized tank is connected to the valve of the plaster mold.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 10. Pressure inside the mold is slowly increased to 0.85 kpa (0.123 psi) using air from the compressor and is maintained for a total of three hours. During this time, the liquid porcelain will condense to approximately 13 millimeters (0.5 inch).
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 11. A 5-millimeter (0.2 inch) straw is placed into the plaster mold.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 12. Air is slowly pumped into the mold through the straw with an automatic bicycle tire pump.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 13. Pressure from the compressor pushes excess slip out through the hose.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 14, After the excess slip is removed, the clay is dried for three hours and then the wooden frame is removed.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 15. The process of removing the plaster mold.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 16. After removing two sections of the mold, the last section is propped up with a wooden board.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 17-18. The mold is elevated so that the wooden board becomes its base.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 19. The last section is slowly separated from the work.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 20. The slip-cast work right after the last section of mold has been removed.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 21. The work is left to dry completely.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 22. The artist checks the progress of drying.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 23. The artist corrects slight distortions that occur during drying using various tools, for example, metal tools such as a Tungaloy knife, and sandpaper.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 24-25. The artist scrapes, shaves, and sharpens the form with the knife shown in step 23.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 26. Sandpaper is used to polish the work and complete the finishing touches to the form.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 27. Dust and impurities are removed from the surface with a wet brush.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 28-29. After bisque firing in an electric kiln at 850°C (1562°F), the artist’s seihakuji glaze is sprayed onto the surface with a spray gun.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 30. The process of reduction firing. The firing lasts 30 hours. Firing temperature is set at 1250°C (2282°F), while the reduction temperatures of 860°-1180°C (1580-2159°F) are achieved through liquefied petroleum gas firing.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 31. The fired work inside the kiln.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014

description: 32. The unglazed parts of the works are polished or removed with a polishing machine. A wooden base designed by the artist is attached, and the work is now completed.
contact: Roma sent Fukami an email 10/7/2014 for all photography permissions, Fukami accepted 10/22/2014
